DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 25 October, on motion by Mr Free:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had the opportunity—I would not call it the pleasure—to be here yesterday during some of the earlier stages of the debate on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. Before I go to precisely what I want to say, I wish to make some comments about the contribution from the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) who spoke for his full 20 minutes and delivered what was mainly a tirade about the federal government closing off—from the way he put it—any educational opportunity for people in remote areas. He was particularly hostile about hostels for rural school students and I want to put his comments into some context. With the program he was talking about, the changes under this piece of legislation mean that, out of a $3 billion set of programs, we are looking at a cut in a $1 million program, which was really there to provide seed funding, anyway, and a number of states have already picked up some of the recurrent funding issues there.

PARA.TAB: It is sad that we had to endure that tirade. Certainly, while the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) was trying to make his contribution, he had to put up with constant haranguing from the other side from the member for Kennedy, who was saying that people were not terribly interested in rural and remote areas. I do not think that is the case in any way, shape or form, and it would be disappointing if people in the Kennedy electorate gained that impression from him.

Rural and remote issues are very important because they are an element of what is important to the Labor Party, and that is educational opportunity across the board, regardless of where you live or, for that matter, of how much money your parents have. But I would like to concentrate what I have to say today on issues that relate to not a small number of people—certainly in terms of the Australian population—in Kennedy. The member for Kennedy talked about `one vote, one value' yesterday, and there are 80,000-odd people in his electorate, as in most other electorates; but I want to talk today about 25 per cent of the Australian population, and that is the people of Victoria.

The Commonwealth is in a very difficult position when it comes to education, because it does not have much power, in many ways, to direct where the money that we are talking about in this bill will go. We have just had reports from the National Board of Employment, Education and Training which really point out two aspects of these particular issues. One is `Resources and accountability for the Commonwealth funding for scenarios for government primary schools' for the next four years, and the other is another review into the level of Commonwealth government recurrent funding to government primary schools.

What is very clear in these reports is also increasingly tragically evident in human terms on the ground, as far as the potential for Australian school children, and particularly Victorian school children, is concerned, and that is that the state government is ripping money out of the education system. The Commonwealth government, on the other hand, is putting it in, and what we will see will be a pipeline effect for a generation of children and young adults going through the education system in Victoria. There will be an impact which will affect their opportunities in life, and an impact which will affect the economy of that state and, therefore, of Australia.

Since the Kennett government came to office, it has cut $400 million out of education in Victoria and closed 300 schools. The member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) is constantly trying to bring this matter up in support of his constituents, to point out the impact not only on education but also on country towns in his electorate, which is a vast one, relative to the rest of Victoria. The impact that those sorts of cuts are having on the economies of towns and, certainly, on the opportunities for children to gain proper education is astounding and, in many cases, quite demoralising.

The government of Mr Kennett, the Premier of Victoria, has cut $400 million out of the state school system; he has closed 300 schools; and he has sacked 8,000 teachers. Now a lot of those skills have been lost to our community, probably forever. In many cases those teachers are going to New Zealand, and I will come back to that shortly. He has cut expenditure by 10 per cent, whereas the Commonwealth has increased expenditure in real terms over that same period by 1.5 per cent. So the Commonwealth has funded Victorian education through that index to pay wage increases for teachers. He has not passed them on. He has closed schools. And now the Victorian government will not even participate in the nation's literacy survey.

We had a number of contributions here yesterday from people concerned about the problems of literacy in our community, yet the Victorian government refuses to participate, along with the Western Australian government. Does that not point to something—that the Western Australian and Victorian governments refuse to participate in a national literacy survey?

It was really quite surprising, considering the comments by the Liberal candidate for Jagajaga in the next election. She sent out a letter to all her would-be constituents, and she said that Victoria's truancy and literacy problems are more than a little disturbing. I have to agree with her. But she, like most Liberal candidates and members of parliament, have yet to come up with the goods; they have yet to come up with the solution. We would never see them going out and attacking Mr Kennett, who has cut $400 million, sacked teachers, increased class sizes and put incredible pressure on all elements of the school system in Victoria. They will not talk about that in terms of literacy. They will not even talk up here in the federal scene about what their alternatives are in terms of an education policy.

I would be very surprised, but I would be very happy, to hear contributions from members of the National Party or the Liberal Party about what they are going to do as an alternative. It is no use just coming in here; it is getting a bit late for that. The clock is ticking away out there in the electorate. They might think they are having a good run now, feeling pretty pumped up, but, once the heat goes on, they have to put those policies out there some time. The later it is, the harder it is going to be to sell them. But the problem is that they will not be able to sell them because people do not believe anyone who has gone on for so long hiding policies from them, particularly when they can see what Liberal-National Party governments do when they are in office. They cut health and they cut education, and certainly in so many ways we have seen that happen now. Not only do they cut it; they take resources out of the system in other ways.

One of the biggest problems for the federal government is to get accountability in health, education or any of these joint Commonwealth-state programs, any of these areas where money is allocated for specific purposes into state government programs. Education is one of the most critical areas. Health is obviously very important but, when it comes to education, we are talking about the future. It is very hard to rectify these discrepancies and these weaknesses in an education system for generations to come. It has an incredible pipeline effect.

If there are any dollars that a government, state or federal, is going to spend out of revenue from taxpayers, then surely education is one of the most critical areas of government expenditure. It has an impact on so many things. It has an impact on our economy, and it has an impact on our society in ways that often cannot be measured but, in many ways, can be measured with great precision. It has an impact on the opportunities that people have, the ability for our most valuable resource—our human resource—to be provided with the skills, the ingenuity and innovation to contribute to the economic wealth and growth of this country. Yet we see that conservative state governments, time after time, cut education, push down wages and bring in incredibly restrictive workplace arrangements and legislation—as we have seen in Western Australia only too recently. At the same time, they find all these ways to reduce their accountability so that they siphon off the Commonwealth dollars which are there for specific purposes.

The Commonwealth has a number of quite clear objectives in education which give opportunities for people to maximise our human and economic resources. The Commonwealth's objective is to strengthen Australian schools by assisting schools to provide educational services of the highest quality, to prepare students for life in general and for full participation in society, including participation in a skill, to create an adaptable work force, to promote equity within schools and society—we do not hear much of that from the others—and to maximise retention rates, especially among groups which currently have low rates of retention. One of the great successes of the government over the last decade has been the way in which we have been able to build that retention rate from one of the lowest in the OECD to one of the highest.

Just the other day I was sending out best wishes and kits to the school leavers finishing year 12 in my electorate. When I started doing this eight or nine years ago, I had plenty left over after having distributed 500. This year I have distributed over 1,500. That shows the success of the government's policies and expenditure in building up retention rates so that our young people go through to the end of year 12 and get the maximum opportunity to participate in TAFE or further education, or even just to go from there and take a break to learn some life skills.

The government's programs are also there, particularly in primary school funding, to facilitate the transition from primary to secondary school. We have seen even greater advances in facilitating the transition from secondary school to further education.

I want to draw a few parallels. I have said a few things about the federal government's money being spirited away by Liberal-National Party state governments in places like Victoria—they are not the only ones—where we have seen $400 million being sucked out of the system, 8,000 teachers being sacked and the Commonwealth's real increase in expenditure in schools education being undercut and knocked down by the incredibly drastic 10 per cent expenditure cuts.

Let us look at the ideal that is held up by those opposite about the wonderful land of the long white cloud. The student-teacher ratio in primary schools in New Zealand in 1993 was about 25.5 to one; in Australia the ratio is 18.4 to one. In secondary schools in New Zealand the ratio was 17.5 to one; in Australia the ratio is 12.4 to one. New Zealand has not invested long-term expenditure in training teachers and now they are importing teachers from Australia. Talk about a brain-drain! Think of the dollars we have spent developing the skills of Australian teachers. Now New Zealand is trying to suck teachers out of Australia—all too willingly provided by the likes of Jeff Kennett—to go over there. That is a great loss to our system.

Look at how the conservative government in New Zealand has failed its people. It is no wonder they have some economic success, but at what cost? Sure, it is easy to be the cheap, white trash of Asia if we want to have people with a low standard of education working in factories at absolutely minimum wages, which is the sort of thing that is being promoted by those opposite.

The proportion of all students in New Zealand who stayed on to form 7—the equivalent of year 12 in Australia—increased from approximately 15 per cent in 1980 to more than 50 per cent in 1993. From 15 per cent through to 50 per cent is one thing, but between 1990 and 1993 the number of students who completed form 7 increased from 33 per cent to 38 per cent. The equivalent school retention rate for year 12 in Australia in 1993 was 76.6 per cent, up from 71.3 per cent in 1991. That is a big difference. Some of the economic commentators who only think of the short term might think that there have been some great successes over there, but at what price? What price is New Zealand society paying for such poor performance in education?

What will be the price to Australian society—and we will see the effects in a very short time—of pulling $400 million from the Victorian education system? The Minister for Education has been absolutely abysmal in his public relations and in his performance in Victoria. He pulls out $400 million and then a couple of weeks back he makes a big announcement about how he is putting $50 million back in. The principals to whom I have spoken—and there are still a few who are game enough and brave enough to talk to people outside of the Liberal Party in Victoria—do not cop that. The school communities do not cop that. Those school communities have been asked to take the cuts and to go out into the poorest areas and find hundreds of thousands of dollars to keep their schools running.

Free education is an absolute myth in Victoria. It is okay for the people who live in rich and wealthy suburbs where their kids go to government schools. They have all of the professional people, and that is where all of the big fundraising and sponsorship goes on. That is what they call `schools of the future' in Victoria—if you have got the money, if you have got the clout, you will do okay. But where is the support for the schools in the low income areas such as the West Heidelbergs of the world? What hope have the kids in those areas got? The state government does not care; it is quite happy for people to be in that situation. The people there are either unemployed and live on social security paid for by the federal government or they are used, under the Victorian industrial relations system, as cheap factory fodder. And, for that matter, if the opposition should ever come to power in this country, federally, we would have deeply repressive national industrial legislation.

It is very clear that education is something that has to be improved on in terms of our federal system and in terms of accountability. One of the basics of that is literacy. It is about time that the Victorian government stopped talking about the schools of the future and started investing in the schools of the here and now. Without developing and participating in national literacy surveys, and without putting real money into education, Victoria will go backwards. We have the opportunity to go forward now. Manufacturing and many other aspects of the Victorian economy are starting to move.

We have had to undergo, probably more than any other state in Australia, the most drastic restructure to get our economies and our industries—so many of which are manufacturing based—away from protection and from the old ways. The Victorian people have done that. They have done it hard, but they have survived. They have built new industries. But now they are having to pay another price for their efforts, by having their children ostracised in this process of vast cuts and, indeed, by the lack of accountability between federal and state funding.

The one big issue facing Australia as it goes into the 21st century is not about the flag or whether we have a President or a Queen, and all the rest of it; it is about federal-state relationships. What sort of country are we going to have? Is it going to be one that is a collection of 19th century colonies, as those opposite would have it, inhabiting a big continent, having a common currency and interstate trade policies and a common defence? Or is it going to be one where there is true national progress, where the states and the Commonwealth work out, through constitutional reform, the realities and get some consistency? It is about time that some of the people in state governments woke up, instead of harbouring a parochial small-minded attitude about their hangovers from the 19th century.

What have we seen from the opposition? We see them going back to state taxes and the same old ways of promoting the states at the expense of national Australian policy. You cannot talk about an Australian flag unless you have an Australian attitude. I am afraid that national attitude is seriously lacking in the opposition. They are at the behest of their state Liberal and National party organisations, and this is reflected in their very parochial attitudes. There has to be accountability for federal grants to the states. On this occasion the federal government's money will be spent to overcome the deficiencies of state governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been interested and amused by the statement by the member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples). His remarks, which went way beyond the scope of the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995, indicated that this is a very wide ranging debate. The only thing he did not mention is the need for more priority funding for the Pacific Highway. I am surprised he did not do that, because I know he would share my views on that particular point.

PARA.TAB: I was also interested to hear the previous speaker mention that the issues of the flag and republic are not the major issues confronting Australia today, or in the future beyond the next election. I was surprised that he should focus on federal-state relationships as the major issue facing Australia.

I see the major issue facing Australia as unemployment—jobs and future security for all Australians. That should be the absolute priority. I take this opportunity to refute the furphy raised by the honourable member for Jagajaga when he was talking about the opposition advocating state taxes. This is not true. In the lead-up to the election campaign the government will continue to put forward falsehoods, which will have to be hit on the head every time.

In the spirit of fairness the government has to be applauded for its funding of the programs in this legislation—for instance, the extension of the early literacy program to 1996. Literacy is a major problem right around this country. I do not believe that most Australians realise the extent of the literacy problem.

The government will provide grants to foster literacy development for children in their early years of schooling. Next year, government schools right around Australia will receive $6.666 million, while non-government schools will receive $2.208 million. The idea of the program is great, but the level of funding is ridiculous—it is farcical. If the government were fair dinkum, they would be spending far more than this.

If we are going to talk about the need for literacy, we should certainly pinpoint our Aboriginal community, and perhaps the Torres Strait Islanders as well. Next week, as part of the inquiry currently being conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, I will be chairing hearings at Ernabella and Nepabunna. The committee has been to many places around Australia. You cannot help but be appalled at the extraordinarily high level of illiteracy.

Education is the key to the future of Aboriginal Australians. I believe that education has failed Aboriginal Australia. In my capacity as deputy chairman of the committee I speak to many Aboriginal people, not only in my own electorate but right around Australia, and it is horrifying to find the level of illiteracy. Without literacy and without education those people are doomed. I applaud the government for what they are doing, but it is too little too late.

Another budget initiative reflected in the bill is the new program of grants to non-government special schools, to assist students with disabilities to make the transition to mainstream education or to pursue further training for employment. Again, that is wonderful and I applaud it. But how much are we providing for the whole of Australia? It is $3.22 million. This is only window-dressing; the scope of the problem is far wider. Three million dollars right around Australia for a whole year's program is quite laughable.

I am also perturbed that the government is going to do away with the gifted and talented children's program. Let us face it, if we take as an example the former Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, he continually spoke about the clever country. We do need to be a clever country. I believe we need to foster and give support to gifted, clever, talented kids. This is a resource we cannot afford to waste.

I notice that we spend a very large amount of money on children with disabilities, and I do not begrudge one cent of that expenditure, I think it is absolutely vital that we do that, but we are very short-sighted because, while we are spending a great deal of money to help those who have some sort of a disability, we are now walking away from the gifted and the talented children. If we are to be a clever country, if we are to succeed and increase our productivity and make our economy more efficient, then we need all the brains we can get. We need to foster and help clever, talented people. I think it is a great pity that they are doing this.

I would also like to mention the cutback of funding for hostels for rural school students. My area, which is the mid-north coast of New South Wales, is not remote but there are remote areas around Australia where, without a hostel, kids cannot get education at all. I find it very strange that speaker after speaker from the government can stand up and talk about equity and fairness and bucket us in the opposition as though we do not care and as though they are the owners of all caring and all compassion. It is not true. Then you come to the reality of the situation. It is not a great deal of money that they are talking about but it is just one more thing that is going to make it harder for those kids who live in isolated areas to get a decent education.

As I was saying about our Aboriginal Australians, education is the key. It is the key for everybody. A good education is needed, particularly these days. It might have been the case that decades ago you could make it on your own, but not these days. I will give you one example of a person who did make it on his own several decades ago. Ulrich Ellis, who worked in this parliament as principal private secretary to Sir Earle Page, Fadden and McEwen and who was later campaign director for the New England New State Movement—a wonderful man and author of several books—failed the Intermediate examination. That was his proud claim. He was a brilliant man who was successful and did make it without a formal education. However, that is not possible these days and unless we provide education for all of our people we are doing a great disservice to every individual. Without an education they just cannot enjoy life to the fullest, and literacy is the key.

I will return to the first point I was making and that is the paucity of funding being provided for the literacy program. I wish that more could be provided. I know, as everybody else does, that Australia is broke after 13 years of financial administration by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Look at the balance of payments problem and all the other factors. I will not go into them now. Australia is broke. It is like when the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) was Minister for Land Transport and I would always be talking about the Pacific Highway and asking for more funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —As you are now.

—Yes, as I am now and will continue to do. You have to realise that you have to balance things up and set priorities. Literacy education has to be an absolute priority. Unless we are concerned enough and care enough to make the commitment, then we are going to go out backwards. We cannot just rely on the enormous number of dedicated and committed people who are involved in our schools as teachers or administrators or even the parents and friends bodies that do such an absolutely marvellous job.

PARA.TAB: As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, I get a lot of schools coming from my electorate to visit Parliament House and I make a point of spending a lot of time with them. It is a truism, of course, to say that those kids are the future of Australia, but they are. Even if they are coming down on non-sitting weeks, if I possibly can I will come down especially and meet the kids when they come in. I will have them for two or three hours and bash their ears about democracy—I use that phrase, which always amuses them—and about the importance of parliament and the great things that we have in this country. We take democracy for granted—we really do. There is only a handful of countries, 20 or 25, where anyone can get out and do what I do in every federal election campaign, which is to stand on the street corners with a microphone and say what I think quite freely about parliament and government, with no secret police across the street and nobody with a submachine gun around the corner.

As I say to the kids, you just have to look at your television screen any night of the week to see what is going on elsewhere and realise how lucky we are to be in this country—even though it does have a Labor government—and to enjoy the facilities of freedom and liberty and democracy that do not exist in most countries in the world. Those teachers who come down here, sometimes with 70, 80 or even 150 kids, and give their time, at night and in travelling with them, do a wonderful job. In the context of the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 I would like to pay tribute to those teachers who are involved with those schools coming down. They do a fantastic job.

It is not just the government schools; the private schools that I have in my electorate do a wonderful job. They do not all manage to get down here. For instance, I have three Seventh Day Adventist primary schools—at Coffs Harbour, Kempsey and Macksville—who do a great job and they generally combine with some others to come down. Mirriwinni Gardens Aboriginal Academy—right up at Nulla Creek, where Slim Dusty was born, on the upper Macleay—is doing a great job with Aboriginal kids, not just from our area but from all over Australia. We have two Rudolf Steiner schools—Chrysalis, which is a secondary as well as a primary school, and Casuarina—which are doing a good job and providing the variation in education that is so important to give people the option of having something different. And, of course, the Catholic school system does an absolutely fantastic job, both in primary and secondary schools. Without that, the impact on state governments in providing education would be unbelievable. It is absolutely essential that that system is supported and continues; otherwise, if it were to disappear, the stresses placed on state government systems would be totally insupportable.

There are a number of smaller schools. It is interesting that they seem to be proliferating and expressing various views, particularly in the Christian schools. We have a new Anglican school in Coffs Harbour, Bishop Druitt College, and at Kempsey there is the very small Heritage Christian School. There are also the Christian community schools. We have an excellent high school at Bonville, near Coffs Harbour, and two branches of the Christian community school in the primary area—one in Coffs Harbour and one at Nambucca Heads. These people are doing a wonderful job as well.

There are even quite small schools, such as the Coffs Harbour Bible Christian School. The last time I was there it had only 19 students, so it is very tiny. But they have the freedom in this country to do their own thing and I think that is very important indeed. Another of these is the Tallowood School at Bellingen, and so it goes on. All of these schools are doing a wonderful job, but all are in need of a little more funding. To come back to my main thrust, we have to acknowledge, we have to realise, that without education this country cannot go anywhere and we have to place the emphasis on education for every kid in Australia.

I note that the member for Jagajaga was suggesting that, in Victoria, the schools in poorer socioeconomic areas were disadvantaged compared to those in richer areas. If so, it is a great pity. I suppose that, if their average level of income is higher, the support for the school from the parents is likely to be higher as well. But I understand what he is saying, because the electorate of Cowper has the second lowest level of per capita income of any federal electorate in Australia. We, in Cowper, are not rich people. We have got an enormous number of unemployed. The last figures were somewhere about 18 to 19 per cent. It becomes 15 to 24 per cent in the 30s, and teenage unemployment is over 50 per cent.

Those figures are from the last time we got the figures. As everybody knows, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training—or, if not him personally, certainly his department—has hidden and stopped the distribution of the regional figures of teenage unemployment. I think it is a great pity that they are so ashamed of the unemployment figures—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not right.
—My friend might protest, but it is true. They are no longer available. They have been stopped.
—I got some this morning for the Mornington Peninsula.

—Perhaps the Labor members are getting them. But there is discrimination against opposition members by this government, and we do not receive information that is given to Labor members. I know that to be true.

PARA.TAB: To return to the bill, Mr Deputy Speaker, the main thrust has to be money for education. I want to emphasise the point that, in my electorate, we have a number of disadvantaged schools. I am not conversant with the Victorian system, but in the New South Wales system the disadvantaged school system does work. They are provided with extra facilities and extra funding.

As I have said, my electorate is not remote in any normal sense. But there are one or two schools right in the backwoods, so to speak. Collombatti Rail is a very tiny school in the Macleay Valley, but it is well equipped with computers and all sorts of equipment. This I applaud. At least in the New South Wales school system—at present, at least—there is some fairness and there is some equity. If Victoria is not employing the same form of system for disadvantaged schools, I hope that Victoria will see what New South Wales is doing.

Again, I come back to the main theme that without education we hamstring our young people. This is why, as I said at the beginning, I applaud the government for introducing these things. But the level of funding is really joke. It is just not satisfactory at all. Of course, literacy and numeracy—this is simple and basic—are the key. I will go back to the point I made at the beginning: under $9 million for government and non-government schools throughout Australia, for the whole of 1996, really is a joke. I want to conclude by saying that every dollar we spend on educating our kids and every dollar we spend on educating older Australians is a dollar well spent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I talk on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995, I would like to make a few comments on the contribution of the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). He said that he brings school groups into this house and speaks to them—bashes their ears—about democracy. I congratulate him; that is good. I wish he would come down to Victoria and bash the ear of the Premier of Victoria about democracy, because in local government we do not have democracy. He has sacked all the councillors and he has hand-picked, in my electorate, three members of the Liberal party to be in charge of the 100,000 people in Frankston. These three hand-picked Liberal members—not past members, current members of the Liberal party—are controlling the whole of Frankston.
—That is a better vote than Saddam Hussein got!

—It probably is—100 per cent. We talk about democracy, but it does not happen in Victoria. It is about time some people up here actually had a go at Jeffrey `Glib' Kennett and brought this to his attention.

PARA.TAB: This is a very important bill. It brings into force some of the government's initiatives. I was particularly impressed with the idea of the extension of the early literacy program. This should be called the Mary Crawford amendment. If I remember rightly, the member for Forde (Ms Crawford) and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training did a lot of work on literacy and numeracy. They produced an excellent report. I am certain the recommendations in that report have influenced the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) to give more money to this particular area.

This is also a good bill in relation to the new non-government schools program for students with disabilities. That is a social justice measure. It is something that the Labor Party should aim for at all times. It is good to see that being implemented.

In my electorate of Dunkley, several schools have received Commonwealth grants for repairs and maintenance. They also receive the general recurrent per capita grant. In 1994, that grant added up to over $6 million, and the capital grants program added up to over $300,000. Thus, for capital grants, maintenance, new schools, science blocks and so on, the schools in my electorate have received over $7 million in grants over the years. That is quite a large amount.

Children start their education in kindergarten. In about 1945, I was one of the first pupils at the first free kindergarten in Victoria. My mother has a photo of me in my jumpsuit with Lady `Someone' opening my kindergarten in Hawthorn.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be in black and white.

—It was in black and white. It was a long time ago. That kindergarten was one of the first free kindergartens in Victoria. What is happening to kindergartens in Victoria now? Local governments, which are controlled by appointed commissars from the Liberal Party, are telling the kindergartens to tender for the job. The people who are working there, who used to work for the councils, will now have to apply under a tender scheme for their job to run the kindergartens. Those positions will be open to competition from private enterprise.

PARA.TAB: If that happens—and this has been pointed out to the government in Victoria—the federal government subsidy for those kindergartens will cease. However, the Liberal government in Victoria is making a concerted attack on kindergartens. I would like to bring to the attention of the House some of the things that are happening.

The Victorian state government has cut funding to kindergartens by $11.5 million or 18 per cent. That has happened since the beginning of 1994. What does cutting funding to kindergartens do? It is estimated that the fees have risen from $40 in 1993 to between $100 and $120 in 1995. In one particular kindergarten, enrolments have fallen from around 94 per cent to about 88 per cent. That is the sort of thing that is happening all the time.
The Aspendale North Kindergarten has recently complained in the Age about what is happening. Aspendale North is close to my electorate, although it is in the electorate of Isaacs. The article says:

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Kay Cafarella is the parents' committee member in charge of enrolments and fees at Aspendale North Kindergarten. She said yesterday that the kindergarten's committee had done everything it could to keep fees down, but has still had to raise them from $35 a term before the cuts to $90 in 1994, and $105 this year and $110 next year.
Jeffrey Kennett is putting this huge impost on average families in Victoria. He is making the parents pay these huge fees at the very beginning of their children's education.

PARA.TAB: What does this do? The people who can afford it—the wealthy people in our community—have no problems paying this sort of fee. However, those who have low incomes, such as single mums and others, cannot afford it, and so their kids miss out on those first years at kindergarten, years which are vitally important for the whole of their education.

I was a member of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training which did an inquiry into bullying in schools. We had evidence before us that was given by kindergarten teachers that this sort of behaviour could be noted when the kids had just started kindergarten. What happens? Once again, for those who cannot afford to send their kids to kindergarten, these faults cannot be rectified and they cannot get those extra couple of years education which really assist. An article in the Herald-Sun of 23 October 1995 revealed that hundreds of children have dropped out of kindergarten halfway through the year because parents cannot afford to keep paying their up-front fees. As I said before, thousands of children in Victoria are being affected because of the impost that Jeffrey Kennett has put on those kindergartens.

I will move on to primary schools. I had a mother speaking to me yesterday and she was complaining that at her child's school, a school in Frankston, they have composite grades of grades 4, 5 and 6. They do not have just one composite grade of 4, 5 and 6; they have three composite grades of 4, 5 and 6, and there are 30 kids in each grade. I said, `Why can't they be separated into three grades, one 4, one 5 and one 6?' She said, `At the present time, they can't do it because there will be more boys in one class than there should be.' That is because of some ludicrous law that is under way in Victoria. Children in grade 6 who are ready to go into high school or whatever they call it now, secondary school or tech school, have got younger kids of grade 4 in their actual class, so naturally they do not get the proper training. This is what is happening to schooling in Victoria, and it is all over Victoria.

If you have a look at what else is happening there, it is not just the children that are being affected; it is also the teachers that are being affected. Teacher numbers in Victoria have been cut tremendously. If the teachers speak out against it, what happens? I will tell you what happens. Mr Kennett commented on the radio that teachers unhappy with the education system should get another job. `They use our children as ramming rods to prove they have their own points, so I have no truck with them at all,' Mr Kennett told 3AW. `I do not see why we should promote teachers who have a record of disruption or withdrawing services.'

That is the sort of thing that Mr Kennett has said. He goes on attacking our teachers all the time, and what can our teachers do? They really cannot get up and say anything against it, because they are intimidated. If they say anything, they will get a promotion to somewhere way outside their area. They will not be working, say, in Frankston if they complain about it. They might live in Frankston, they might have a job in Frankston, but they will end up a long way from their family, in Mildura, Ballarat or somewhere like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lovely places.

—They are lovely places, but when your family lives somewhere in Frankston you cannot afford to actually shift house way up there. This is the sort of thing that the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) mentioned was happening in Queensland in Joh's time. Teachers used to sign a petition against Joh Bjelke-Petersen, their names would be recorded and they would get a promotion to the back of Queensland somewhere. That is what is happening in Victoria now—teachers are intimidated. They are doing a great job. Those teachers that are left after Jeffrey Kennett has sacked and made redundant thousands of teachers are putting up with huge classes. They are doing a good job, but they are intimidated, they are scared to speak out.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at what else is happening in Victoria. The Kennett government have taken $400 million out of education already. That is August 1995, so it is not as if it is going back. They have removed $400 million and they are about to take out another $150 million. We are giving them more money. They are stealing the money and putting it somewhere else. Who knows where it is going. Jeffrey Kennett spent $50 million refurbishing various government buildings. His own offices are like a fortress—you cannot get in there. Supposedly the carpet is about three inches thick. This is the sort of thing the money is going to. It has been taken out of the education funding that the federal government is giving and is going to the contracts of his friends or his mates.

One only has to look at what is happening in Victoria in relation to education and to the casinos. All Jeffrey's mates get whatever they want down there. If they want another casino table, it is a case of, `No worries; here you are, Mr Williams.' If you are a friend of the Liberal Party and if you make a big donation or if you look after his house, maintain the lawns or do a bit of building there, you get what you want. However, if you want to get your kids into schools, there is a bit of a queue. There are 30 in a classroom. There are 271 primary and secondary schools that have been closed in Victoria under the Kennett government. There are 8,200 teachers who have been taken out of the system. Is that doing the education of our children any good? Certainly not. Victoria spends $1,004 per person on education in comparison with New South Wales, which spends $1,108 per person on education. There are similar sorts of figures in social security, housing and recreation, and we can go on.

It appears that New South Wales spends about $300 more than Victoria does per primary and secondary school pupil. Jeffrey Kennett has a committee made up of politicians from his own joint party, and even that committee has criticised what he has done in education. The report is entitled The school global budget in Victoria. The report has been circulating amongst school principals for quite some time now. One of its recommendations was that there was a `strong argument for increasing the overall level of resources for primary schools'. It said that it was time to end the funding disparity between primary and secondary schools and that there was a need for a significant increase in resources for students with special learning needs. It also recommended assistance to small schools in country areas so that they can offer a broader range of studies.

In Victoria, because of these cuts—for instance, the special teachers have been sacked—and the increases in numbers, the state's VCE rates have dropped. The numbers of students staying at government secondary schools has fallen every year since 1992. When was Jeffrey elected? According to figures released by the state government last night, current VCE retention rates were measured at 77.5 per cent in February this year, with a low of 70.6 per cent in July. In February 1992, the retention rate was 84.6 per cent, and in February 1995 it is 77.3 per cent.

When the liberal government got into power, they sent out a lot of direct mail letters. I got a letter from Jeffrey `Glib' Kennett. It was addressed to me; he would not know I was a member of the Labor Party. It said that the Liberal Party has the policies, the team and the determination in Victoria to get Victoria moving in the right direction. He certainly moved it to the right all right. As I said before, he has destroyed democracy in Victoria. He sacks any teacher who speaks out. If the Liberal Party gets elected again and if Jeffrey becomes the dictator of Victoria, I will probably be up against the wall. However, I will not go there quietly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I get the feeling you don't like Mr Kennett.
—Yes, there is something there. This is the sort of thing he sent out.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—The honourable member has the right to be heard in silence and the member for Maranoa will accept the same fair deal when he is speaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jeffrey Kennett has said to me that the coalition is determined to restart small businesses and farms, to get our children off the dole into employment, education and training. The other thing that he has put out, which is quite interesting, was a little item that talked about generating new jobs—30,000 to 40,000 new jobs for Victorians. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Coalition New Jobs Initiative will generate between 30,000 to 40,000 jobs in the private sector by 1994.
The Coalition New Job Initiative will:
.benefit over 30,000 Victorians . . .
.provide a cash incentive to employers who take on new employees;
.apply only to the private sector—

Not one dollar has Jeffrey `Glib' Kennett given to this scheme. I do not think anyone in Maribyrnong has received any money. Has the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) heard of Jeffrey giving this money out?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think they've dipped out badly.

—Yes, I think they have—all over Victoria. He promises this new scheme. Does he deliver? Not on your nelly. And they are having a go at us on jobs! Wait until I start sending this around the electorate and start reminding people about this scheme that he never implemented. It was going to cost $160 million and every employer was going to get a grant. Did any employer see a dollar? Not a dollar. Another item says:

SPEECH.PARA: Private sector employers who take on new employees over and above their Victorian workforce numbers as at 30 June 1992 will receive a cash payment of up to $2,500 per annum for every additional employee.
There has been not a dollar on that. In his speech yesterday the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) said:
A coalition government will encourage greater diversity within the school system and widen opportunities for a parental choice of schooling, rather than centralising the system.
He also said:
The coalition government will improve access for isolated children—
and so on. I would like to read a little article out of the Victorian coalition government's policy, back in 1992. It is called `Giving students a chance' and it says:
The Coalition will empower the community by:-
.Encouraging parents and students to choose the school that best suits their needs . . .
.Having school communities manage resources provided directly to them—not consumed by a central bureaucracy . . .

This is exactly the same sort of thing that the member for Ballarat said yesterday. Here it is in the actual policy statement of the Victorian coalition government. Did they implement it? Yes, they did. What happened? Thousands of teachers were sacked. Hundreds of schools were closed. School classes were increased. What we have here, from the member for Ballarat, is a direct pinch of Jeffrey Kennett's and Don Hayward's policy. I can assure the people of Australia that they should be aware of this. They should go to Victoria and see what has happened to the schools down there.

PARA.TAB: As the time gets closer for the election, we can expect that John Howard would like to distance himself from Jeff Kennett. When I was speaking to a member last night I said, `It won't be too long before John starts to say, "I don't want anything to do with Jeff Kennett—he is not one of us."' And here we have it: in today's Canberra Times, an article says that Jeffrey has come up with a plan to strip the federal government of 80 per cent of its tax take. Then it quotes John Howard as saying, `Jeff and I may have made up, but not that much.' So, already, he is starting to distance himself.

We give the Kennett Liberal government an actual report card. On class size, they fail. On spending per student, they fail. Composite classes—fail. Retention rates—fail. School violence—fail. And on overall performance, they fail. And I believe the most telling comment is the parents' comment: Jeffrey Kennett and team should be expelled after the time that they have been in government. I am quite certain that the opposition's policy, whenever it is released, will also come up with the same sort of report, showing that they also fail. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to contribute to this debate on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. In this bill we see that the federal government is going to honour promises on three-year funding that it made prior to the last federal election. I particularly want to focus on the abolition of a rural hostels program. The bill seeks to implement the announcement in the 1995-96 budget that this program would cease in July 1995. So much for the rhetoric about the federal government knowing and understanding the problems out there in rural Australia. This is despite a commitment from the federal Labor government that the program would be funded from 1994 to 1996. And that was a promise.

PARA.TAB: I am particularly angry that this program has been cancelled, because a number of the hostels which have received funding are in my own electorate. I have been personally involved with the committees which run those hostels, and I have seen the good work and the worth of the program. It was only this year that the Roma Rural Student Hostel received funding of almost $6,000 from this program, for the purchase of a computer, a laser printer, computer software, staff computer training and advertising. It is a very worthwhile program.

Whilst I am here today, I want to put on the public record my support for this program. Unfortunately, it is not going to run its full life. The federal government has broken another promise. The equipment that I referred to in the Roma Rural Student Hostel is vital to the successful operation of that hostel, and in the future its funding is going to be sorely missed.

In May of this year the program provided $1,508 for St Joseph's hostel in Dalby, another rural hostel doing a wonderful job providing accommodation for rural students so that they can gain access to higher education. Those hostels are playing a particularly important role in providing that accommodation for those students. Similarly, the Bollon Hostel received $1,508 for five new student desks, a line filter for power fluctuations, two computer software packages and a first aid training course for two staff members.

One has to understand—and, quite obviously, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) does not understand—that these three hostels are located in areas where there has been severe drought for the last five years. Those amounts of money are extremely modest when you consider the total amount of money that is spent on the education budget. For the people of Bollon at the hostel there, $1,508 has bought some assistance and facilities which would otherwise not have been provided. Of course, the local community was unable to provide it, given the severe recession still out there in rural Australia.

The absence of this funding will place a severe financial burden on these hostel committees and their local communities in the future. That is why I am angry. For $1 million, we are not seeing this program continued for the life of the original promise made by the Labor Party. It is quite clearly a betrayal by the Keating government of the people of rural Australia, all for the sake of trying to get the budget back into some phoney sort of surplus.

Without this hostel scheme, the federal government will be allowing the gap between rural and urban education to widen. I touched on this gap the other day in the House in speaking to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. I made the point there that students from rural Australia are not participating in higher education to the levels of those students from urban Australia.

The 1993 figures show that the year 12 retention rate for students in urban areas was 66 per cent but for the students who live in remote areas the figure was only 52 per cent. In the 1991 census, the population of remote Australia was 12 per cent, but the percentage of remote students enrolled in higher education was no more than two per cent.

The abolition of the rural hostel program will only exacerbate this inequity, and I condemn the federal government for attacking the people and families of rural Australia by failing to continue to fund that hostel program for the life of the original commitment made by the government. It is a particularly callous breach of promise to the people of rural Australia, given the plight of so many families as a result of five long hard years of drought and of what can only be described as the recession that still plagues rural Australia.

I want to touch on some comments made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) in relation to education. He attacked me recently in the Senate about my comments in the rural newspapers of Queensland regarding access to Austudy. These articles stated that farmers had come to see me and said that they would be better off, in many cases, if they did not receive some of the available assistance measures. While that assistance is welcome at the time, when they later go to their accountants, farmers are finding that, in many cases, their entitlement to other assistance measures such as Austudy have been severely cut. Some farmers now actually have a debt to repay to the Department of Employment, Education and Training because they were not entitled to the Austudy that their children had received. This is due to income in the form of assistance that they could not have predicted would be available when they originally applied for Austudy.

I want to refer to what Senator Bob Collins said in the upper house, because he seemed to think it was a bit of a joke. My comments in the newspaper were in response to representations from farmers out there at the coalface; they were comments representative of the views of people out in rural Australia. Senator Collins was criticising me for saying that assistance arrangements for farmers makes it difficult to predict their income for the year ahead. He was trying to defend these arrangements. It is difficult for farmers to estimate their income, and this is one of the difficulties which people from rural Australia have in applying for Austudy, because to predict their income—and the seasons, as well—is virtually impossible.

One of the schemes that is certainly providing much needed help to many farmers in rural Australia is the rural adjustment package, but it is really just a lottery. Minister Bob Collins obviously does not understand that the income that farmers receive—whether from a drought relief payment or as an interest subsidy—goes towards their family's taxable income for that year. I have got a farmer's budget figures here, but before I read those into the Hansard I wish to state that in the last 13 months the Queensland Rural Adjustment Authority has received 5,994 applications for assistance. If you are one of those farmers out there applying for assistance, you really do not know whether you are going to get it and how much you might be going to get. Of those applicants, 4,826 were successful and 1,168 were not successful, so it becomes an absolute lottery to know whether you are or are not going to get that assistance.

A farmer came to see me recently about this problem, and I actually have in front of me his family budget: that is how concerned he is about the issue—unlike Senator Collins, who thinks it is a joke. This farmer applied for an interest subsidy and he thought that it was right to assume that he would probably get an amount similar to his entitlement in previous years. The drought worsened and the Rural Adjustment Authority looked at his application and realised that, unless he got substantially more assistance, he was a possible risk of foreclosure. The authority recognised his plight, caused by five years of long hard drought and a mouse plague in the area, so he received almost double the level of assistance provided the year before.

That farmer had budgeted for a figure of about $11,000 in assistance. I will not read out the figure that he actually received, but it was double his budgeted figure and a bit more. At the end of the financial year when Austudy did a review of his need for Austudy assistance, it found that his dependent children were not entitled to full Austudy, because that assistance was treated as family income. This meant that those children were tripped out of the top level of Austudy. As a result of an assistance measure, the farmer has now to repay some $10,000 in Austudy that has been paid to the students. It was welcome assistance but it has tripped them out of the top level of Austudy.

When the minister said that the assistance meant that predicting the farmer's income for the year was difficult, there was laughter in the Senate chamber. Of course it is difficult, and it is even difficult to predict when you are or are not going to get financial assistance in the form of an interest subsidy. The figure of 1,168 farmers who missed out on the subsidy clearly indicates that some get it and some do not. Those who get it cannot budget for it in the financial year, because they do not know whether they are going to get it or how much it might be. In this case, receiving it meant that the farmer's income was higher than he had predicted on the application for Austudy assistance and so, at the end of the financial year, he found that he then had a debt to repay. Whilst the assistance is certainly welcomed by farmers, the complex and uncertain way of receiving it is creating a downside for the rural sector.

Minister Bob Collins went on to say that farm families receiving a drought relief payment—which is another form of assistance and is all about putting food on the table for these families—are excluded from the Austudy assets and income test for the time they are on drought relief payments; that is, for the period of the drought and for a further six months following that. That is true; but, if families are not on drought relief payments for the financial year 1995-96 and they apply for Austudy this financial year, whilst they may have been on Austudy in the previous financial year, that drought relief payment is considered—in terms of their access to, or eligibility for, Austudy—as income for the previous financial year.

While the farmer is on the drought relief payment, that is fine; but, if he trips out of it because of the arrival of a welcome, come-by-chance crop, the farmer then goes off drought relief payment. This is because, if he is not entitled to it, he is going to have to pay it back, as he has to in the similar case of Austudy. This particular farmer actually took his family off the drought relief payment because he realised that he was not entitled to it. With the failure of the winter crop, he then reapplied in the next financial year and, because he was not on drought relief payments, the Austudy income and assets test did apply.

This case demonstrates how little the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy knows—or cares, for that matter—about this issue, because he seemed to make a bit of a joke of it in the upper house. But I do understand the issue, because I am representing these people on a day-to-day basis. I do not think there has been anywhere in Australia in the last 30 or 40 years a drought area worse than we have seen in the Darling Downs and south-west Queensland. Unfortunately, the drought has come on top of the collapse of the wool price and the corruption of the international commodity market for grain, and it has come on the back of the highest interest rates that this country has ever seen. Farm after farm is in a desperate situation.

Whilst these assistance measures have been welcomed by the farmers, they also create other consequences and problems down the track. Farmers cannot accurately predict their income or the source of any financial assistance that may be coming from the Commonwealth and, because of that, we see that the consequences of providing assistance to the rural sector, particularly Austudy, are not understood.

The minister ought to think again before he says this issue is a joke. The fact that he took the time of the Senate to attack me on this issue shows quite clearly that my comments are hurting him. They are accurate comments which have come from farmers of my constituency. They are also comments that are supported by accountants who do the books for these people. These people have presented their farm budgets to me. They have also shown me the amount of assistance they are receiving. One thing about rural people is that they never like to talk about the amount of debt they have or the amount of tax they pay. They are very private people. They have had to swallow an enormous amount of pride to show me exactly what they have received.

I must condemn the actions of the federal government in breaking a promise in not continuing to assist those rural hostels to the tune of another $1.1 million for just one more year. I would have thought the minister would have looked again at this issue. Students are part of the next generation of people to live in rural Australia. They are the beneficiaries of the rural hostels program, which has been well received and has delivered some wonderful facilities to students who would not otherwise have been provided for. Obviously, the minister has been rolled by the Treasury officials, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the cabinet. He obviously has very little authority.

In conclusion, it demonstrates that the Labor Party has no understanding of the plight of rural communities in Australia. The Labor Party always thinks, `If we throw a bit of money out there they'll keep quiet, they'll be happy.' They do not understand the complexities of budgeting in rural Australia and the complexities of rural economies. They certainly do not represent the best interests of the students of rural Australia. The abolition of the rural hostels program one year prior to when it was meant to conclude in this funding round demonstrates that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join the debate on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 because it gives us an opportunity to develop an important theme that is now before the politic national, that is, Commonwealth-state relations. Education—especially primary and secondary education—is a field where the responsibility is shared between the states and the Commonwealth government. It is interesting to have a look at the way in which that cooperation takes place in various states.

PARA.TAB: A number of my Victorian colleagues have spoken on this side of the house. In Victoria we are seeing some of the worst aspects of Commonwealth-state relations where there is an unequal sharing of the responsibilities. It is in primary and secondary education in Victoria—amongst other things such as hospitals—where we see that because the states are given the greater power they reach outcomes that are not in the best interests of the people who live in the state and do not fulfil the outcomes that the federal government would like to see.

My interest in this bill first came about because I noted that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free), in his second reading speech, provided supplementation of capital and recurrent grants to reflect movements in costs. One of the things that has galled me in Victoria is that there is very little recognition, especially towards capital works, of the Commonwealth's contribution to projects in government schools. In fact, the Kennett government, in using capital works in education as part of its grand plan to get infrastructure spending and capital works projects on the go, completely ignores the contribution that is made by the Commonwealth.

Whilst Minister Free has endeavoured, with great gusto, to ensure that the states—in this case, the state of Victoria—understand their obligations under the various Commonwealth-state agreements, still at the edges the Victorian government tends to try to slink through and not acknowledge at any point, in what it is doing, how much contribution is made to capital works projects. For instance, in the development of the Mill Park Secondary College, which is the only post-primary school in a suburb that now has 30,000 residents, and is growing at a great rate of knots, something like $4,445,000 of the capital money used to build that school was federal money, was Commonwealth money. As each stage is developed and each stage opens, whether it is informally or formally, there is very little recognition—very little to no recognition—of the contributions that are made by the Commonwealth government.

That is something that we really need to look at, because the people of Victoria need to understand that, despite Jeffrey `Glib' Kennett—as the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) so often refers to him—making glib comments about the nature of Commonwealth-state relations, a lot of income tax moneys that are raised are returned to the state. In some way the Premier thinks that he is a great national figure and he has the interests of the nation at heart, but we had him yesterday coming up with this notion, in commenting on the comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about a referendum on whether the states should be able to raise income taxes or not, of suggesting that, I think, 80 per cent of all income tax and company tax should just be handed over to the states.

As I said in an adjournment speech earlier this week, I do not think that the people of Victoria would welcome a suggestion that we are going to give even more power to a Premier such as Jeff Kennett. It is just not on. At the worst, they might believe that there needs to be this balancing between what we, as a national government, have as objectives as against what Kennett has as his objectives for his state government. At best, I suppose, I would like to believe that we, as a national government, can work in the national interests, which are also in the states' interests. I reject this notion that somehow, as we approach the centenary of Federation, we should revert back to Australia being still a collection of six colonies. This is nonsense. As we develop a maturity on the international scene, as we understand the need for us all to work together, we really need to act as one nation. If the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) mentions the importance of the Pacific Highway, that is done in a context that it is not only important to his local electorate but important on the national scene.

TALK.START.PARA: —National significance.

—It is of national significance and that is why, as a good local member, he continues to boost that up. And slowly but surely he will succeed—perhaps more slowly than he would like. It is proper that in a national context we take a project like that and assess it. This notion that it is something that New South Wales should worry about in isolation is just out of the question.

PARA.TAB: When we look at a government education system, whether it be in Victoria, Western Australia, New South Wales or wherever, we have to remember that what happens in that education system will have a definite impact on what is happening to Australia as a nation. That is an important consideration, and it is disappointing to hear, through the comments that have been made by the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party (Mr Costello) and by a state Liberal Premier in Kennett, that the coalition is unclear in what it would have for the nation with respect to Commonwealth-state relations. I unashamedly believe that we should be moving towards national policies.

When we talk about national policies, it does not necessarily mean that we are talking about centralist policies. We have to recognise that, in a country the size of Australia, state authorities and local authorities have a role to play. They are perhaps better placed in the delivery process, and in that delivery they should be working to a national framework. As I said, I cannot understand why the Victorian government, in its mealy-mouthed way, will not recognise the contribution that is made towards capital works projects in government schools. I contrast that with the attitude of non-government schools, schools in the Catholic system or schools that are run by other organisations. When they join in an agreement with the Commonwealth government about the capital funding of their project, they are quite happy to fulfil the requests that are made of them. In my electorate, when we had the opening of things that we have made contributions to in the Catholic system, they are quite happy to recognise the involvement of the Commonwealth.

Earlier this week, in an adjournment speech—and I am sorry the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) has gone—I raised what I thought was a genuine concern that should interest the House about the Better Cities project. One element of the Better Cities project in my electorate is that some surplus institutional land, which was used as a psychiatric institution, has now become available for housing development. In setting up a proper community approach to this housing development, a number of state departments, local agencies, the Urban Land Authority and others have got together to work up models of what should be included in this development. Unfortunately, the one state administration that is not cooperating properly is the school education division.

In the corner of this site is the Bundoora Primary School, which has, I think, been there for over a hundred years. Slowly but surely development has impinged upon its site. On one boundary we have a six-lane road with the light rail—the tram that was built with money from the Better Cities project—running down the middle of it. This main road serves the suburb of Mill Park. On the other boundary of the school, we have part of the western ring road, the link to Greensborough, so it has a major road on either side of it. Over a number of years, this school has endeavoured to get the department's agreement to find an alternative site for it. The school basically services the suburb of Bundoora. It has a definite catchment which was widened two years ago when a neighbouring primary school was closed, under the Kennett government's unilateral closure of schools.

What it has been offered is a site which services one of the housing developments in the suburb of Mill Park. There is nothing wrong with the site, but what the department does not seem to understand—I just wonder whether they are ensconced in Nauru House or some other ivory tower—is what is happening at a community level. If they are suggesting that this local school should move to that site, what they are saying is that the existing school closes and they build a new school. If that is the decision that they have come to, that is the way they should package it; they should not gloss it up in any other manner. The importance of the Better Cities land is that the present Bundoora Primary School is in the corner of that land. A proper housing residential development would give consideration to whether there was a need to have a primary school on it. On the basis of the number of residential allotments it is possible, and I believe quite probable, that there should be a school within this development.

At the moment, DSE, the appropriate state authority, will not even enter into discussions to have that kept open, as a suggestion. At a public meeting that was held at the Bundoora Primary School, one of the officials said, inter alia, that they would not be told by anybody where they were going to put their schools. This is a disgraceful and unfortunate attitude. As I have said in letters to the Bundoora Primary School community, at the end of the day wherever the new school is to go is probably not the question at this stage.

All I am asking is that the members of the school community have all the facts before them so that they can have a considered view about where the possible new school would go. What it is about is whether it should be a relocation of Bundoora Primary School—that is, a true relocation where they could move to a site that might be half a kilometre or a kilometre away—or, as I described before, whether it should be closure of the school and the building of a school some four or five kilometres up the road which would serve a totally different catchment area. I accept that these decisions need to be made from time to time, because the demographics of the areas in which schools operate change. It is not simply because Bundoora Primary School has been there for, I believe, over a century. It is not just a historical basis that justifies the school continuing; it is proper planning that is required.

This has been an opportunity for a number of my colleagues to quite rightly express their disquiet, through to disgust—wherever they fit on that sort of scale—about what is happening with education in Victoria. Some $400 million has been ripped out of the budget; there has been the closure of some 300 schools; there is the loss of some 8,000 teaching positions; and there is the move towards different managerial styles that have been, unfortunately, instituted overnight with very little regard for the school communities and the school councils to be able to absorb that change. That is a problem.

I have no problem with school councils having a greater say in the way in which their schools operate. I think that is proper. But when we do that, when we devolve to school communities greater decision making, we have to recognise that they need to be given the support in making those decisions. That is where the inequity between what we would describe as disadvantaged areas and advantaged areas is even worsened, because it is not just economic inequities, it is also skills inequities. It is all right in suburbs where we have people that are managers in their own right and understand the complexities that are placed upon and by the bureaucrats within the education department. It is not all right where people are doing this out of concern, a desire to assist in the proper education of their children, where they are being exposed to new notions and it is done without proper support and training. That is wrong.

It is a bleak picture in Victoria. I want to mention two articles in the Melbourne papers this morning. One article mentions that the state Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education visited a school for the opening of a room that had been destroyed by fire. The room has been replaced by using insurance money. I believe that, after a considered view—and probably quite rightly—a number of teachers went to the gateway in protest at this visit. Whilst the teachers have been told that they were going to be treated as professionals and that there would be a partnership with teachers, we have seen very little evidence of this over the last couple of years.

Another article in this morning's Herald-Sun is entitled `School calls in fundraising pro'. As the member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples) mentioned, under this notion of the schools of the future program, schools are being encouraged to do more and more fundraising. In this case, we have the story about a secondary college at Hoppers Crossing, in Melbourne's west, that is seeking a professional fund-raiser to bolster revenue for new computer equipment. This is after it wrote to over 140 local businesses to try to get contributions of up to $30,000 to cover the costs.

The notion is that people try to get the local community involved in this type of sponsorship for the schools, but it is nonsense to believe that this is going to happen equitably across the socioeconomic stream in Melbourne suburbs. It is unfortunate that the time of teachers, principals and parents is being tied up chasing these things to achieve some sort of equity in the education of their children.

I think the people of Victoria reject this notion and style of administration of education. It is unfortunate the way this responsibility for education is shared: there should be a greater balance as far as people's involvement is concerned. The government tries to achieve this within reason without making it an imposition. It tries to set in place national policies over a whole host of areas but, unfortunately, from time to time, it gets frustrated and it does not get the cooperation that it expects from state administrations.
